Award.AwardTitle: TWC SBE: Medium: Collaborative: User-Centric Risk Communication and Control on Mobile Devices

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Risk communication is an important part of many cyber security mechanisms. Android's current risk communication mechanism is based on security warnings and has been demonstrated to be ineffective because users become habituated to ignore such warnings and tend to consent to all prompts. This multi-disciplinary research project aims at developing holistic solutions to usable risk communication and control for the Android platform.

This project investigates an approach that presents risk information at multiple granularities, including a high-level numerical risk summary, an intermediate-level summary of risk for different dimensions, and detailed risk information. The high-level risk summary is computed by information integration techniques, using information discovered from multiple sources, e.g., user reviews and app source code. This summary enables proactive risk communication (e.g., when the user searches for apps) so that users can take this information into the decision process.

This project also introduces a multi-mode approach that, in addition to communicating risks, also controls risks in the sense of discouraging risky applications and ensuring that users truly understand the risks. The project develops mechanisms that aggregate, communicate, and control risks incurred by apps at runtime, and ways to personalize risk integration, communicate, and control techniques to accommodate differences among users.

This project is expected to advance the state of the art in principles and techniques to risk communication and control, and has the potential to impact the Android app ecosystem by collaboration with Google researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As mobile platforms, such as Android, become more and more sophisticated, it is increasingly challenging for ordinary users to understand the implications of permissions requested by apps and make sensible decisions when installing apps from a variety of developers. To remedy the problem, rather than only blandly indicating the permissions requested by apps, we argue that it would be much more effective to convey the potential risks associated with apps. In particular, we observe that simple one-dimensional risk categories (e.g., low, medium, high) could not capture the complex nature of apps as well as the decision making process of users. The goal of the project is to develop effective techniques to mine a variety of indicators of apps, including permissions, developer information, app metadata and user comments, and identify the dimensions/categories of different types of risks so that risk information can be presented with more detail.

 

To develop an indicator of risk that decomposes risk into several categories, this project conducted two studies designed to assess the dimensions of risk deemed most important by experts and novices. The firs study is composed of semi-structured interviews of 19 security experts, who identified three major risk dimensions: personal information privacy, monetary risk and device availability/stability risks. In study 2, 350 typical Android users, recruited via Amazon Mechanical Turk, filled out a questionnaire about their device usage and their risk assessment process when installing apps. We found that in general the typical users’ concerns were similar to those of the security experts. The results of the studies suggest that risk information should be organized into several risk types that can be better understood by users and that a mid-level risk summary should incorporate the dimensions of personal information privacy, monetary risk, device availability/stability risk and data integrity risk.

The quality of app reviews has a direct impact on the risk analysis of apps. And it is common that attackers inject fake reviews to influence users. Besides content-based techniques in the literature to detect fake review, this project developed a novel technique to detect spammer communities based on user interactions (commenting each other). Experiments show that it is possible to reveal implicit stronger than random relation between users who do not have explicit social connections. Combined with sentiment analysis, such relations could be further used to discover spammer communities without relying on sophisticated (and often easy to evade) content features. The accuracy of this structure-based technique is comparable to existing content-based techniques. These two types of techniques thus could be leveraged together to fight against fake reviews in practice.

This project also developed privacy preserving techniques of general data analysis tasks (including clustering and preference queries) that could be utilized to perform app risk analysis while protecting user privacy. These techniques are built on differential privacy, a rigorous formal privacy concept widely adopted in the literature as well as in industry. The proposed technique takes into consideration the special properties of waveclustering data analysis and skyband queries, and optimizes the noise adding process accordingly to strike a good balance between privacy protection and accuracy of analysis results.
